questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)?
questions.solution:
The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a universal blueprint for addressing global challenges by 2030, focusing on interconnected goals such as poverty, inequality, climate action, and sustainable growth, with a commitment to "leave no one behind".

Option (a): SDG 10: Reduced Inequality

  • Reduce inequality within and among countries.

Option (b): SDG 4: Quality Education

questions.text: Who developed the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Morris David - The PQLI was designed to provide a more holistic understanding of well-being compared to purely economic indicators like GDP per capita.

TIPS AND TRICK - PQLI Indicators can be remembered by LIE.

  • L - Life Expectancy at age one (measures health and longevity).
  • I - Infant Mortality Rate (measures child health and survival).
  • E - Education (Literacy Rate) (measures access to education).

Incorrect options:

Option (a): Paul Ehrlich - He developed the concept of chemotherapy and made significant contributions to immunology. He discovered the first effective treatment for syphilis.

Option (b): Sir Ronald Ross - Ross's work remains a cornerstone in the fight against malaria and has saved countless lives by improving our understanding of disease transmission.

Option (d): James Lind - He discovered the cure for scurvy. James Lind's discovery of the role of vitamin C in preventing scurvy marked a turning point in medical history.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Morris David developed the Physical Quality of Life Index. The three indicators combine to assess the general well-being and quality of life in a population.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park, 27th Edition, chapter-2, Page number.17

questions.solution:

questions.text: Time interval between primary and secondary case is:
questions.solution:
Serial Interval

Definition:

  • The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in the primary case (the person who initially contracts the disease) and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case (the person who contracts the disease from the primary case).

Importance:

  • It helps in understanding the transmission dynamics of an infectious disease.
  • It is used to estimate the potential for disease spread and to inform public health interventions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Serial interval is time interval between primary and secondary case

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-02, Page number:36-40.

questions.text: After cholecystectomy surgery, Patient is in which state?
questions.solution:
• After cholecystectomy surgery, the patient is typically in the state of Impairment.
  • Refers to a loss or abnormality of physiological or anatomical structure or function.
  • After cholecystectomy, the patient may have a change in digestive function due to the removal of the gallbladder, which is an impairment.
  • Option (a): Disease: Refers to a pathological condition affecting the body or mind, but does not specifically apply to the post-surgical state.
  • Option (c): Disability: Refers to a restriction or lack of ability to perform activities of daily living due to an impairment. This may not directly apply immediately after surgery unless the impairment affects daily functioning.
  • Option (d): Handicap: Refers to a disadvantage that limits or prevents the fulfillment of a role that is normal for the individual.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Refers to a loss or abnormality of physiological or anatomical structure or function.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-02, Page number:44-48.

questions.text: In a study, patients of lung cancer were matched with normal healthy controls by age, sex, environment, place of residence and social class. the frequency of cigarette smoking was then compared in the two groups. What type of study was this?
questions.solution:
The type of study described is a case-control study (option d).

  • In a case-control study, patients with a particular condition or disease (cases) are compared to individuals without the condition (controls).
  • The study looks retrospectively to compare exposures (like cigarette smoking) between the two groups to identify any associations with the disease.
  • In this scenario, lung cancer patients (cases) were matched with healthy controls, and the frequency of cigarette smoking was compared between the two groups, which is characteristic of a case-control study.

Key features of a case-control study:

  1. Retrospective Nature: Case-control studies look back in time to compare exposure histories between cases (those with the disease) and controls (those without the disease).
  2. Comparison of Groups: The study involves two groups: cases, who have the outcome or disease of interest, and controls, who do not.
  3. Matching: Cases and controls are often matched on certain characteristics (e.g., age, sex, social class) to minimize confounding variables.
  4. Exposure Assessment: The study assesses past exposure to a risk factor or intervention to see if there is an association with the outcome.
  5. Efficient for Rare Diseases: Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases or outcomes, as they do not require following a large cohort over time.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In a case-control study, patients with a particular condition or disease (cases) are compared to individuals without the condition (controls).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-03, Page number: 71-80.

questions.text: What is the best method to change health attitude and behavior?
questions.solution:
The best method to change health attitudes and behaviors is typically group discussion.

  • Group discussions are effective because they allow for interactive communication, peer influence, and the sharing of experiences and perspectives.
  • This interactive format can lead to a deeper understanding and greater motivation to change attitudes and behaviors.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The best method to change health attitudes and behaviors is typically group discussion. This interactive format can lead to a deeper understanding and greater motivation to change attitudes and behaviors.

questions.text: As there is an increase in incidence of blindness in village near commercial area of delhi. The government of delhi decided to increase awareness among village people by promoting national programme for the control of blindness and visual impairment, you are a health officer appointed for this awareness program, so what is the most likely cause of blindness in india?
questions.solution:
Cataract is a major cause of blindness and visual impairment, particularly in older adults. While other factors such as glaucoma, refractive errors, and vitamin A deficiency also contribute to visual impairment.

Awareness programs for cataract prevention and treatment can be crucial in reducing blindness rates.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cataract is the major cause of blindness in India.

Reference: NATIONAL HEALTH PROGRAMS OF INDIA, 12th Edition, J. Kishore, chapter-19, Page number: 518-523.

questions.text: Bhopal Gas tragedy (1984) is an example of
questions.solution:
The Bhopal Gas Tragedy (1984) is an example of: B. Single source, continuous exposure epidemic

In this tragedy, a large amount of toxic gas (methyl isocyanate) was released from a single source (a chemical plant), and people were continuously exposed to the gas until the leak was contained. This continuous exposure from a single source led to widespread health effects in the population.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The Bhopal Gas Tragedy (1984) is an example of Single source, continuous exposure epidemic

questions.text: When disease frequency is measured over a long period of several decades, it is called as?
questions.solution:
When disease frequency is measured over a long period of several decades, it is called Secular trend

Secular trends refer to long-term patterns or trends in disease frequency over extended periods, such as decades, and help to identify changes in disease incidence or prevalence over time.

KEY TAKEAWAY: When disease frequency is measured over a long period of several decades, it is called Secular trend
